test.defenition: a procedure intended to establish the quality, performance, or reliability of something, especially before it is taken into widespread use.
test.example: "both countries carried out nuclear tests in May"

test.defenition: take measures to check the quality, performance, or reliability of (something), especially before putting it into widespread use or practice.
test.example: "this range has not been tested on animals"

test.defenition: the shell or integument of some invertebrates and protozoans, especially the chalky shell of a foraminiferan or the tough outer layer of a tunicate.

trim.defenition: make (something) neat or of the required size or form by cutting away irregular or unwanted parts.
trim.example: "trim the grass using a sharp mower"

trim.defenition: decorate (something), typically with contrasting items or pieces of material.
trim.example: "a pair of black leather gloves trimmed with fake fur"

trim.defenition: adjust (a sail) to take advantage of the wind.
trim.example: "her jobs include trimming the spinnaker and dealing with the yacht's plumbing"

trim.defenition: additional decoration, typically along the edges of something and in contrasting colour or material.
an act of cutting something in order to neaten it.
the state of being in good order or condition.
trim.example: "no one had been there for monthsâeverything was out of trim"

trim.defenition: the degree to which an aircraft can be maintained at a constant altitude without any control forces being present.
trim.example: "the pilot's only problem was the need to constantly readjust the trim"

trim.defenition: the way in which a ship floats in the water, especially in relation to the fore-and-aft line.
trim.example: "ships' masters had to check trim and stability before departure"

trim.defenition: neat and smart in appearance; in good order.
trim.example: "she kept her husband's clothes neat and trim"
